questions.question: What is the first step in the CompTIA A+ six-step troubleshooting process?
questions.explanation: The first step is to identify the problem by gathering information from the user, identifying user changes, and performing backups before making changes.

questions.question: What is the recommended temperature range for optimal computer operation?
questions.explanation: The recommended temperature range for computer operation is 45°F to 90°F (7°C to 32°C) to prevent overheating and ensure optimal performance.

questions.question: What should you always do before cleaning internal computer components with compressed air?
options: Hold fans to prevent them from spinning
Remove all components from the case
questions.explanation: Always hold fans in place when using compressed air to prevent them from spinning too fast, which can damage the bearings or generate harmful voltage.

questions.question: What is the recommended humidity range for computer equipment?
questions.explanation: The recommended humidity range is 10% to 80%. Too low causes static electricity buildup, while too high can cause corrosion and component damage.

questions.question: Which troubleshooting approach uses a step-by-step manual to diagnose problems?
questions.explanation: The follow-the-path approach uses manufacturer documentation or step-by-step diagnostic manuals to systematically troubleshoot issues.

questions.question: When should a computer's internal components be cleaned?
options: According to the environment and manufacturer guidelines
questions.explanation: Cleaning frequency depends on the environment (dusty areas need more frequent cleaning) and manufacturer recommendations, typically every 3-6 months.

questions.question: What type of cloth should be used to clean an LCD screen?
questions.explanation: A lint-free microfiber cloth is recommended for LCD screens as it won't scratch the surface or leave lint behind.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of computer overheating?
questions.explanation: Dust buildup in fans, heatsinks, and vents is the most common cause of overheating as it blocks airflow and insulates heat-generating components.

questions.question: In the troubleshooting process, what should you do after testing your theory?
options: Establish a theory of probable cause
questions.explanation: After testing your theory, if confirmed, you should implement the solution. If the theory is not confirmed, establish a new theory.

questions.question: What is a sign that a CMOS battery needs replacement?
options: Incorrect system date and time after power loss
questions.explanation: A failing CMOS battery typically causes the system to lose date/time settings and BIOS configuration when power is removed.

questions.question: Which tool is best for testing a power supply?
questions.explanation: A power supply tester is specifically designed to test PSU functionality and voltage outputs quickly and safely.

questions.question: What should you do with old batteries and electronic components?
questions.explanation: Batteries and electronic components contain hazardous materials and should be recycled according to local environmental regulations.

questions.question: What is the 'divide and conquer' troubleshooting approach?
options: Starting with the most complex component
Testing at a middle point and narrowing down from there
questions.explanation: Divide and conquer involves testing at a middle point in the system, then systematically narrowing down the problem area by eliminating working sections.

questions.question: What causes most hard drive failures?
questions.explanation: Most hard drive failures are due to mechanical wear of moving parts or physical shock/vibration damage to the read/write heads or platters.

questions.question: When documenting a problem, what information is LEAST important?
options: Customer's personal opinions about the cause
questions.explanation: While customer input is valuable, their personal opinions about the cause are less important than factual information like error messages, reproduction steps, and configuration.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a POST card?
options: To diagnose boot problems using POST codes
questions.explanation: A POST card displays Power-On Self-Test codes to help diagnose hardware problems that prevent the system from booting properly.

questions.question: Which cleaning solution should NEVER be used on a computer monitor?
questions.explanation: Ammonia-based cleaners can damage anti-reflective coatings on monitors and should never be used. Use water or monitor-specific cleaners instead.

questions.question: What is a common symptom of failing RAM?
options: Random system crashes and blue screens
questions.explanation: Failing RAM typically causes random system crashes, blue screen errors, application crashes, and system instability.

questions.question: How often should thermal paste be replaced on a CPU?
options: Every 2-5 years or when experiencing overheating
questions.explanation: Thermal paste typically needs replacement every 2-5 years, or sooner if the system experiences overheating or the cooler is removed.

questions.question: What is the best way to discharge static electricity before working on a computer?
options: Touch an unpainted metal part of the case
questions.explanation: Touching an unpainted metal part of the computer case while it's plugged in (but powered off) safely discharges static electricity.

questions.question: Which log in Windows Event Viewer contains hardware-related errors?
questions.explanation: The System Log in Event Viewer contains hardware-related errors, driver issues, and system component failures.

questions.question: What should you do if a theory is not confirmed during troubleshooting?
options: Establish a new theory or escalate
questions.explanation: If a theory is not confirmed, you should establish a new theory of probable cause or escalate the problem to a higher level of support.

questions.question: What is the most important factor when choosing replacement parts?
questions.explanation: Compatibility with the existing system is crucial to ensure the replacement part will function properly with current hardware and software.

questions.question: What tool is used to test network cable continuity?
questions.explanation: A cable tester is specifically designed to test network cable continuity, wiring configuration, and identify faults in cables.

questions.question: Which component failure often causes a 'clicking' sound from the computer?
questions.explanation: A clicking sound often indicates a failing hard drive, specifically the read/write heads repeatedly trying to access data unsuccessfully.

questions.question: What is the purpose of keeping a maintenance log?
options: Identify patterns and schedule preventive maintenance
questions.explanation: Maintenance logs help identify failure patterns, track component lifespans, and schedule preventive maintenance to reduce downtime.

questions.question: When should you perform a backup before troubleshooting?
options: Only if requested by the user
questions.explanation: Always perform a backup before making changes during troubleshooting to prevent data loss if something goes wrong.

questions.question: What causes capacitor failure on motherboards?
questions.explanation: Capacitors fail due to overheating, poor ventilation, age, and sometimes poor manufacturing quality, often showing bulging or leaking.

questions.question: Which Windows utility can automatically fix disk errors?
questions.explanation: CHKDSK with the /F parameter can automatically detect and fix file system errors and bad sectors on hard drives.

questions.question: What is the 'bottom-up' troubleshooting approach?
options: Starting with the most expensive component
Starting with the most basic components first
questions.explanation: Bottom-up troubleshooting starts with the most basic components (power, cables, connections) and works up to more complex components.

questions.question: What should you check first when a computer won't turn on?
questions.explanation: Always check the most basic elements first - ensure the power cable is connected and the outlet is working before investigating complex issues.

questions.question: How can you prevent ESD damage when storing components?
questions.explanation: Antistatic bags provide protection from electrostatic discharge when storing sensitive electronic components.

questions.question: What is a common cause of intermittent problems?
questions.explanation: Intermittent problems are often caused by loose connections that make contact sometimes, or thermal issues that occur only under certain conditions.

questions.question: What information should be included in troubleshooting documentation?
options: Problem description, steps taken, and solution
questions.explanation: Complete documentation includes the problem description, all troubleshooting steps taken, the final solution, and any follow-up recommendations.

questions.question: When is it appropriate to escalate a problem?
options: When it exceeds your knowledge or authorization level
Only at the end of your shift
questions.explanation: Escalate problems when they exceed your technical knowledge, require authorization you don't have, or need specialized tools/expertise.
